title: 111_hr5644
content: The Act titled "End Big Oil Tax Subsidies Act of 2010" includes a provision for the amortization of geological and geophysical expenditures. The "End Big Oil Tax Subsidies Act of 2010" includes an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, changing the term "major integrated oil company" to "covered large oil company." A "covered large oil company" is defined as a taxpayer that is a major integrated oil company or has gross receipts exceeding $50,000,000 for the taxable year. The amendment in section 52 treats it as one person. A conforming amendment in section 167(h) includes "and other large taxpayers" in the heading. These amendments apply to expenses incurred after December 31, 2010. Section 3 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exempt taxpayers who are not small, independent oil and gas companies from certain provisions. This amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2010. Additionally, Section 4 introduces an enhanced oil recovery credit. SEC. 4 introduces an enhanced oil recovery credit for small, independent oil and gas companies, with an exception for taxpayers who are not categorized as such. This amendment applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010. SEC. 5 amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude intangible drilling and development costs for non-small, independent oil and gas companies. The amendment applies to expenses incurred after December 31, 2010. SEC. 6 amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt non-small, independent oil and gas companies from percentage depletion. It also includes an aggregation rule for determining company size. The amendment is effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2010. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code exempts non-small, independent oil and gas companies from percentage depletion. It includes exceptions for qualified carbon dioxide disposed in secure geological storage. The amendment treats persons as a single employer and applies to expenses incurred after December 31, 2010. SEC. 8 limits passive activity losses and credits for taxpayers who are not small, independent oil and gas companies. SEC. 9 addresses income from domestic production activities. SEC. 9 amends Section 199 of the Internal Revenue Code to exclude income from oil and gas production for non-small, independent companies. It applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2010. The amendment to Section 472 of the Internal Revenue Code prohibits major integrated oil companies from using a specific inventory method starting in taxable years after December 31, 2010. Taxpayers affected by this change must initiate and implement a new accounting method for their first taxable year after the enactment of the Act. The amendment requires taxpayers to make changes with the consent of the Secretary of the Treasury. The adjustments needed under section 481 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 must be spread out over a period of up to 8 taxable years. SEC. 11. Amendment to section 179C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 prohibits expensing for refineries processing liquid fuel from tar sands, shale, or coal, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2010.
